security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-only skill containing only documentation and guidance for Git workflow enforcement. No executable code files exist. The skill uses standard file operations (Read, Write, Grep, Glob, Bash) appropriate for its stated purpose of validating commits and creating templates.

content.value_statement: Teams struggle with inconsistent commit messages and branch names that make tracking changes difficult. This skill validates Conventional Commits, branch naming patterns, and PR templates to keep your repository organized and automated changelog-ready.
actual_capabilities: Enforces branch naming conventions (feature/, bugfix/, hotfix/, release/)
Creates pull request templates with checklists
Detects existing conventions from project files
Creates git commit templates for consistent messages
limitations: Does not automatically install git hooks on user systems
Does not modify remote repository settings
Does not enforce policies on team members
Only provides guidance; actual commit creation requires user action

use_cases.title: Standardize Team Workflows
use_cases.description: Ensure all team members follow the same commit conventions for cleaner history and automated releases

use_cases.title: Guide Contributors
use_cases.description: Provide clear commit and PR standards for external contributors through templates and validation

use_cases.title: Automate Release Processes
use_cases.description: Enable automated changelog generation and semantic versioning from properly formatted commits

prompt_templates.title: Validate Current Commits
prompt_templates.prompt: Check if our recent commits follow Conventional Commits format. Show me any commits that do not match the pattern and suggest corrected versions.

prompt_templates.title: Create Feature Branch
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a branch name for adding user authentication with OAuth2 support. Then show the conventional commit format for the first commit.

prompt_templates.title: Generate PR Template
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a pull request template for our project. Include sections for description, type of change, testing, and checklist items.

prompt_templates.title: Audit Git Hooks
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a commit-msg hook script that validates Conventional Commits format before allowing the commit.

best_practices: Use imperative mood in commit messages (add, not added)
Reference issues with Closes #123 or Fixes #456
Separate type from scope with parentheses
anti_patterns: Using generic messages like 'fix bug' or 'update code'
Skipping the scope in commit types when applicable
Creating large commits with unrelated changes
Merging without squash for feature branches

faq.question: What tools support Conventional Commits?
faq.answer: standard-version, commitizen, commitlint, and semantic-release all work with Conventional Commits format.

faq.question: What is the maximum commit subject length?
faq.answer: Keep subject lines under 50 characters. Many tools truncate longer messages.

faq.question: How do I integrate with GitHub?
faq.answer: Place PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md in .github/ directory. GitHub automatically uses it for new PRs.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only reads files you specify and writes templates you request. No data leaves your system.

faq.question: Why are my commits not generating a changelog?
faq.answer: Ensure commits follow the type prefix (feat:, fix:) exactly. Tools skip commits without proper format.

faq.question: How does this compare to commitlint?
faq.answer: This skill provides guidance and templates. commitlint is an automated tool that rejects invalid commits.
